title: Should I buy short scale bass or long scale bass? (I am 190cm tall). Help me please. - Quora

response.answer_text: Pick one you like the sound of. Short and long scale basses DO sound different… not because you can’t shape the tone, of course you can. But the scale length means the string responds differently to the amount of energy circulating in it. A plucked string gets a little stretched when it is vibrating hard, which means it starts out sounding sharp and falls back to its true pitch. Shorter scale means lower tension, which means the amount you put in to play it is larger, which increases this effect. That’s a major thing in ‘djent’ guitar, they’ve tuned the guitars with their really short scales to bass notes, and the pitch is all over the place. If you like pure and tight intonation, you want a long scale. I love my multi-scale Dingwall’s 37″ B-string… that’s really long. A double bass is typically 43.5″, I really like mine because it has an extra-long 45.25″ scale. But I’d never say you were wrong to like a short-scale bass. I just like them long. While I’m reasonably tall (179cm) I have quite small hands (size medium gloves). I’ve seen 155cm women playing double bass… your height has nothing to do with the scale lengths you like to play, or are physically capable of playing. Take a look at this picture of the Dingwall to see what the differences actually are (this is my actual instrument):  The scale lengths on this bass are 33.25″, 34″, 34.75″, 35.5″, 36.25″ and 37″. A “standard” scale is 34″, the same as the second-shortest string on that ABZ. A “short” scale is typically 32″ or a little less, about where the first fret is on the shortest string on the ABZ. Ibanez make some “micro” scale basses at 28.8″, about where second fret is. Guitar scale lengths are around 5th or 6th fret on this bass. The width of the picture is very close to the standard double bass 43″ scale… and mine is another 2.25″ more than that. You might look at that and think it would be very hard to play… not really, you get used to it in a few minutes, and after playing it for a few hours it feels completely natural.

Used to be, the scale of the bass kind of mattered because bass pickups and amps were pretty primitive. There was a tonal difference, so the sound you were seeking (and the kind and length of strings) all figured into scale length. These days, you can sculpt tones so much with gear (and bass pickups/strings have improved a lot) so it’s more a matter of using a bass that doesn’t tear up your body, and a scale that fits your hand size comfortably for the style you play. There are no rules, other than sometimes a trade-off between a bass that looks really cool but might be physically limiting. There’s a minor drawback to short-scale necks in that they encourage playing the bass more like a guitar. Basses with longer scales make it harder to play ‘scaley’ or ‘chordy’ kind of bass and make you focus more on thumping out rhythms. That’s usually a good thing on the bass.
